text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

IRM 4.23.18.1. New subsection, Program Scope and Objectives. Rearranged existing IRM content to place information involving internal controls for a program IRM under this subsection to conform to the new rules to ensure that the program’s internal controls are adequately expressed in the IRM.
Former IRM 4.23.18.1, Overview, deleted and moved to IRM 4.23.18.1.1, Background.
IRM 4.23.18.1.4. New subsection, Program Objectives and Review.
4.23.18.2.4(2). Included a note that a determination of the worker’s status as an employee or independent contractor may impact the treatment of income and deductions on the Form 1040.

IRM 4.23.18.2.4(7). Added that any discussion of a potential tax effect (computational adjustments, reclassiﬁcations of Sch C expenses to employee business expenses, etc.) should be done at the conclusion of proceedings
IRM 4.23.18.3.3. Added a list of campus addresses for protective claim
This material supersedes IRM 4.23.18, dated February 6, 2017.
Examiners coordinating worker classiﬁcation issues between the SS-8 Program and
Coordinating Worker Classiﬁcation Determinations Between SS-8 Program and Exam 4.23.18 page 1
Purpose: The procedures in this IRM are intended to coordinate worker classi- ﬁcation issues between the SS-8 Program and Examination.

The Employment Tax Program is governed by Policy Statements and other internal guidance that apply to all Service personnel regardless of operating division. The Policy Statements found in IRM 1.2.1, Servicewide Policies and Authorities, Policies of the Internal Revenue Service apply to all employment
Employment tax issues and examinations. Examiners should review these Policy State- ments to properly perform their examination duties. (

, relating Delegation Orders, in a single, electronic source. (
) IRM
provides Servicewide instructions for all operating divisions with employees involved with the correct ﬁling, reporting, and payment of ment taxes. IRM

serves as the foundation for consistent employment taxes by various IRS operating divisions. By providing one of authority for all operating divisions, the Service greatly reduces and procedural inconsistencies. (
) Director, Specialty Examination Policy, is responsible for the procedures updates addressed in this IRM. (
) Director, Specialty Examination, is the executive responsible for operational compliance. (
) Chief, Employment Tax Examination, is responsible for ensuring general mation about basic employment tax examiner responsibilities. (
) Director, Exam - Field and Campus Policy, reports to the Director, ters Examination, and is responsible for the delivery of policy and that impacts the ﬁeld and campus processes including the SS-
program. (
) Program Goals: The processes and procedures provided in this IRM are sistent with the objectives or goals for Employment Tax - Examination that and addressed in IRM
, Employment Tax Examination and for ment Tax Policy, found in IRM
, Employment Tax Policy. (
) Program Effectiveness: Program goals are measured with Employment Embedded Quality Performance Reports that monitor whether quality are applied uniformly and consistently. (
) Annual Review: Employment Tax Policy - Program Manager, is responsible reviewing the information in this IRM annually to ensure accuracy and consistent tax administration. (

) Program Reports: Information regarding the reporting of program are included on, but not limited to, the following reports: • Headquarters Examination Monthly Brieﬁng, • Program Manager Monthly Brieﬁng, • Examination Operational Review, and • Business Performance Reviews. (

SS-8 Program Issues determination letters to workers and ﬁrms regarding the proper classiﬁcation of workers performing services for the ﬁrm (i.e., employee or independent contractor). Section 530 Section 530 of the Revenue Act of 1978 provides employers with relief from federal employment tax liabilities resulting from the reclassiﬁcation of individuals as employees if three requirements are met.

Relief. The examiner should consider contacting the worker, and other workers in the same class, to conﬁrm the facts presented on Form SS-
and obtain any additional tion. Contact made with individual workers constitutes a third-party contact. See IRM

If the case is assigned to an examiner, the group manager will provide the name of the examiner to the SS-

) The tax examiner will keep the Form
examination open until the SS-
Technician completes the worker status determination. (
) The SS-

Technician will follow normal procedures for gathering information necessary to make the determination and for issuing a determination letter, however a determination affecting a return open in the ﬁeld will be worked an expedited basis. The SS-
Technician’s determination is based on law factors (usually indicative of the degree of behavioral/ﬁnancial control the worker and the relationship of the parties). (
) At the end of the determination, a copy of the determination letter will be provided to the examiner. (

) Upon receipt of the determination letter, the examiner will continue the nation and make the appropriate adjustments based on the determination of whether the worker is an employee or independent contractor: • If the worker is determined to be an independent contractor, then the worker may deduct properly substantiated business expenses on Schedule C against the income. The worker is generally subject to employment tax on the net income on Schedule C. The worker may deduct the deductible part of the self-employment tax from gross income in determining adjusted gross income. • If the worker is determined to be an employee, then the income is properly reported as wages on Form
, line
The worker is to employee FICA on Form
, Uncollected Social Security and Medicare Tax on Wages. The worker is not entitled to deduct on Schedule C. Prior to tax changes starting in
, any business expenses are employee business expenses deductible on Schedule A subject to the

% AGI limitation. The worker is not to a deduction for contributions to a KEOGH. • In addition, if the worker is determined to be an employee, the will make a referral to employment tax for consideration of an ment tax examination of the employer through the electronic Referral System, at https://srs.web.irs.gov/. ) When using an SS-
determination as the basis for an examination, the examiner must ascertain whether:
The conclusions stated in the letter ruling are properly reﬂected in return,
The representations upon which the letter ruling was based reﬂect accurate statement of the controlling facts,
The transaction was carried out substantially as proposed, and
There has been any change in the law that applies to the period which the transaction or continuing series of transactions were mated. See Rev. Proc.

) If the examiner makes the same determination as in the determination the examiner will follow normal procedures for proposing a worker tion adjustment. Classiﬁcation Settlement Program (CSP) procedures must followed if the requirements for a CSP are applicable. See IRM
, ﬁcation Settlement Program. Failure to comply with a determination letter not exclude the taxpayer from qualifying for a CSP offer. (
) The examiner may determine additional or different facts during the tion that lead the examiner to reach a conclusion that differs from the determination. If the examiner disagrees with the SS-
determination, the examiner will follow the procedures below for resolving the discrepancy possible revocation of the determination letter. (
) Before completing the examination and closing the case, the examiner follow the procedures outlined below. that Letters (
) In some cases, the examiner and the SS-
Technician may not agree on proper worker classiﬁcation. In these situations, the examiner will prepare memorandum to the SS-
Unit that issued the determination letter that the examiner conducted an audit of the ﬁrm (taxpayer) and made a different determination than the SS-

determination letter. The should include the following information: a. Taxpayer name, address, and employer identiﬁcation number (EIN), b. The reasons for the determination that the workers should be differently than the conclusion reached in the SS-
determination The examiner will explain the differences in facts determined during examination that were not considered in the SS-
determination, and c. A request that the determination letter be revoked. Note: If the differences described in “b” above are not explained, the SS-
reject the memorandum/information and return it to the examiner. (
) The examiner will attach a copy of the examination workpapers explaining issue, facts, conclusion, and a copy of the original determination letter. (
) Internal Revenue Manual
When using an SS-8 determination as the basis for an examination, the examiner must ascertain whether:

The conclusions stated in the letter ruling are properly reﬂected in the return, The representations upon which the letter ruling was based reﬂect an accurate statement of the controlling facts, The transaction was carried out substantially as proposed, and There has been any change in the law that applies to the period during which the transaction or continuing series of transactions were mated.
In some cases, the examiner and the SS-
Technician may not agree on the proper worker classiﬁcation. In these situations, the examiner will prepare a memorandum to the SS-
Unit that issued the determination letter explaining that the examiner conducted an audit of the ﬁrm (taxpayer) and made a different determination than the SS-

determination letter. The memorandum should include the following information: a. Taxpayer name, address, and employer identiﬁcation number (EIN), b. The reasons for the determination that the workers should be classiﬁed differently than the conclusion reached in the SS-
determination case. The examiner will explain the differences in facts determined during examination that were not considered in the SS-
determination, and c. A request that the determination letter be revoked.
) In some cases, the examiner and the SS-
Technician may not agree on the proper worker classiﬁcation. In these situations, the examiner will prepare a memorandum to the SS-
Unit that issued the determination letter explaining that the examiner conducted an audit of the ﬁrm (taxpayer) and made a different determination than the SS-
determination letter. The memorandum should include the following information:
a. Taxpayer name, address, and employer identiﬁcation number (EIN), b. The reasons for the determination that the workers should be classiﬁed differently than the conclusion reached in the SS-
determination case. The examiner will explain the differences in facts determined during the examination that were not considered in the SS-
determination, and c. A request that the determination letter be revoked.
Note: If the differences described in “b” above are not explained, the SS-8 unit will reject the memorandum/information and return it to the examiner.
